messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
Push my upcoming reminder to tomorrow 5PM.

I’d be happy to reschedule it—could you let me know which reminder you’re referring to (for example, its title or ID)? If you have more than one upcoming reminder, specifying it will help me adjust the right one.
I don't have any more details, sorry.
I’m not sure which reminder you’d like me to move. If you’d like, I can list the upcoming reminders I have on file so you can tell me which one to shift to tomorrow at 5 PM. Let me know!
Sorry, I don't have that info either.

I can still help—you’ve got a couple of options:

1. I can move every upcoming reminder you have to tomorrow at 5 PM.  
2. I can list the upcoming reminders first so you can pick which one(s) to shift.  

Just let me know which approach you’d prefer (or if you’d like something else)!
Just move all of them to tomorrow at 5PM.

messages.name: search_reminder
messages.content: ValueError: No search criteria are given. At least one search criteria should be provided among ('reminder_id', 'content', 'creation_timestamp', 'creation_timestamp', 'reminder_timestamp', 'reminder_timestamp', 'latitude', 'longitude')

messages.name: search_reminder
messages.content: ValueError: Parameter 'creation_timestamp_lowerbound' is smaller than its valid range minimum of 315529200.0.

Sure—could you let me know tomorrow’s date (month / day / year) and the time-zone you’d like the 5 PM reminder to use? Once I’ve got that information, I’ll shift every upcoming reminder to that exact time.
I don't have the date or time-zone info, sorry.

No problem—I just need one piece of information I can’t safely guess: the time-zone (or at least the city/region) so “tomorrow 5 PM” is unambiguous. If you’re okay with me using your device’s default time-zone, just let me know; otherwise, please give me the time-zone (e.g., “US Eastern,” “Europe/London,” etc.) and I’ll move all upcoming reminders accordingly.
